work.p: Edward Grier notes that this scrap contains ideas similar to those found in what would become section 4 of the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself," the section that begins "Trippers and askers surround me" (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 6:2047). However, the idea of a "real life" existing behind the trappings of society is expressed in many places in Whitman's work, so the specific connection to "Song of Myself" is tenuous.

titleStmt.title: For remember that behind all
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: Edward Grier notes that this scrap contains ideas similar to those found in what would become section 4 of the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself." But Grier also indicates that the manuscript could be notes for a lecture that Whitman was planning (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 6:2047). In either case, the manuscript likely dates to the 1850s.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: For remember that behind all

revisionDesc.change: checked; revised repository information in header

body.p: For remember that behind all this show of ostensible life, of every man and woman,—of you hearing me now in these talks, amusements, dress, money, politics, &c. stands the real life of every man and woman of you who hear me now
